title: Bitcoin trader eyes $63K BTC price for new Bollinger Bands 'breakout' - Cointelegraph
content:
Bitcoin (BTC) could be set for historic gains thanks to a simple trend line breakout, a popular trader hopes.

In a Twitter discussion on May 5, Titan of Crypto flagged a rare bull signal on the Bollinger Bands indicator for the Bitcoin monthly chart.

Bitcoin price may see “inexorable breakout”

BTC price action currently impacts sentiment in different ways across various timeframes. While observers are unsure about short-term moves, the consensus remains that Bitcoin’s upside mainly lies ahead as the block subsidy halving approaches.

When tracking what comes next, however, it may be enough to look at past halving cycles, specifically, volatility.

As Titan of Crypto notes, Bollinger Bands on monthly timeframes are setting up a repeat of a breakout event that has occurred only once in each cycle.

In the two previous instances shown on an accompanying chart from 2016 and 2019, BTC/USD broke through into the upper section of the Bollinger Band channel to see significant gains.

Bollinger Bands are a key volatility indicator across price timeframes. They revolve around a 20-period simple moving average (SMA) functioning as a midline, with two standard deviations above and below representing the channel.

These bands expand and contract with volatility and certain events: among them, the price coming into contact with the bands or even breaking beyond them is often considered important by traders.

Currently, the one-month BTC/USD chart shows the price attempting to break above the SMA line, which, if confirmed, would suggest a classic repeat of past bull runs.

Commenting, Titan of Crypto described it as an “inexorable breakout.“

”BTC is about to break its monthly Bollinger Bands base line. And when that happens 1st target will follow inexorably,” he added.

“That would bring Bitcoin to a solid $63,500.”

BTC/USD annotated chart. Source: Titan of Crypto/ Twitter

While not quite enough to match its current all-time high, the price target could come around the point of the halving in one year’s time. How long it will need in reality remains to be seen, Titan of Crypto acknowledged.

BTC price bides its time

Last month, John Bollinger, the band’s creator, himself argued that Bitcoin was at a crucial point on daily timeframes.

Related: Is Bitcoin overbought or oversold? Use Bollinger Bands to find out!

At the time, the price was retesting the SMA line as support, breaking through to range around it. Now, however, it is heading higher toward the upper band, data from Cointelegraph Markets Pro and TradingView shows.

BTC/USD 1-day candle chart (Bitstamp) with Bollinger bands. Source: TradingView

Subsequently, analyst CryptoCon suggested that low-timeframe Bollinger Bands norms remained intact despite Bitcoin’s comedown from local highs of $31,000.

Even with the last drop in #Bitcoin price, this time is still not different for the Bitcoin 3 Week Bollinger Bands!



Large corrections have always taken place after the upper parameter is met AND exceeded, but not a moment before



The price of the upper band is still $35,790 pic.twitter.com/kQol55Ovmh — CryptoCon (@CryptoCon_) April 29, 2023

title: Bitcoin Miners Reap Profits As Mining Difficulty Hits 3-Month Low - NewsBTC
content:
Bitcoin miners have received a boost in profits after the scheduled difficulty level adjustment resulted in a positive balance. This is the first time since February that the difficulty, which controls the issuance of coins on the network, has decreased. Recent data from Braiins showed that Bitcoin computing power experienced a drop of over 45+ EH/s between April 20 and 28. However, this trend has been reversed with the increase in miner profits over the last week.

Despite the recovery of the hashrate to 350 EH/s, it was not sufficient to prevent a 1.45% difficulty adjustment retracement, as stated by Mempool.space. Currently, the mining difficulty level is at 48T (trillions). This change in difficulty level affects the miners’ profitability, as less competition for the reward means increased estimated income for those still connected to the network.

Bitcoin Miners Profit As Hashprice Increases

The current price for Bitcoin hashpower rose to 0.088 USD/TH/day (88 USD/PH/day), up from 0.077 USD/TH/day (77 USD/PH/day) on May 2. This 11.49% increase over three days is a positive development for Bitcoin miners, indicating increased profitability for their operations. The hashprice is a crucial metric for calculating the profitability of a mining operation, representing the value assigned to a unit of computation in dollars per terahash or petahash per day. While the cause of the significant hashrate drop last week is uncertain, the current state of the network justifies the quick reconnection of miners.

Recently, there has been increased interest in BRC-20 tokens, which are used to create memecoins, leading to network congestion in Bitcoin within a few days of their release. As recently reported, this could be a possible factor in the hashrate drop. As a result of this high activity on the network, the fees are now making up 12.4% of the miners’ revenue.

Related Reading: Bitcoin Breaks Out: Experts Predict $36,000 Target As Market Outlook Remains Positive

Bitcoin Commissions Rise After New Ordinals Record

In the wake of the rising interest in tokens that can be registered to Bitcoin through Ordinals, the value of transaction fees paid by Bitcoin users has surged. Within a single day, the average transaction fees have more than doubled. As per the data from Mempool.space, the current transaction fees range from 70 sat/vB to 100 sat/vB. This implies that a transaction of 140 vB (median) would require payment of almost $4 USD to get confirmed within the first few minutes.

Note that the sudden interest in tokens registered through Ordinals is responsible for the backlog of transactions that need confirmation, leading to a surge in average commissions. According to Murch, a Bitcoin developer, the mempool depth has reached 104 blocks despite having 8 blocks per hour for the last six hours. The rise of Ordinals NFTs has not been without controversy, as some Bitcoin maximalists blame this trend for the increased transaction fees that have resurfaced in recent months.

Bitcoin Price Analysis

At the time of writing, Bitcoin is trading around $29,000, up 2% in the last week.

title: Bitcoin Could More Than Double and Hit a New Record High Next Year - Markets Insider
content:
Bitcoin could hit a new record high next year, said Bob Ras, cofounder of blockchain firm Sologenic.

He cited bitcoin halving, which will reduce mining rewards and supply of the token.

The banking crisis and expectations that the Fed will start easing may also lift bitcoin, he added.

Bitcoin has soared more than 74% to start 2023, but the world's most popular token by market cap could more than double by next year, according to Bob Ras, cofounder of blockchain firm Sologenic.

A key catalyst will be the halving process, which is when the reward for miners is cut in half. It's meant to cut the supply of tokens and historically has sparked price increases.

"When bitcoin's halving kicks in a year from now, we'll likely be well on our way past the previous all-time high," Ras told Insider.

That would mean bitcoin soars past the $67,000 level reached in November 2021, up from about $29,000 on Friday.

Advertisement

Meanwhile, bitcoin appears to be front-running the belief that looser policy from the Federal Reserve is on the way, Ras explained.

The Fed on Wednesday hiked rates for the 10th consecutive time, but Wall Street widely expects that to be the last increase of this tightening cycle.

He thinks the token's rally points to a future that is effectively a return to lower rates and more quantitative easing.

Technical indicators, such as long-term moving averages, suggest upside and momentum, he said, but it's the broader landscape that will determine its performance the rest of the year. And he wouldn't be surprised if bitcoin hits $40,000 by the end of 2023.

Advertisement

"Coupled with signs of slowing [economic] growth, the changing macro picture is pointing towards a Fed that will likely soon have to cut interest rates and inject a lot of liquidity into the market," Ras said. "If the Fed doesn't do this, then we could face a serious contraction, punctuated by a possible credit crunch. Either way, all roads appear to be leading to a loosening of monetary policy sooner rather than later."

Ras isn't alone in his bullishness. Standard Chartered published a recent note that said bitcoin could soar to $100,000 by the middle of next year, and Matrixport predicted that bitcoin could more than double to about $65,000 by next April.

A hedge against financial turmoil

As the banking crisis that started with Silicon Valley Bank in March continues to spark contagion fears, more retail and institutional investors have been turning to bitcoin as a hedge, Ras said.

That turmoil re-emerged over the past week as regulators seized First Republic on Monday and sold the bulk of its assets to JPMorgan, triggered sell-offs at regional banks PacWest Bancorp and Western Alliance.

Advertisement

"The banking crisis helped to cement the narrative of bitcoin serving as a key store of value that lacks the sort of counterparty risk of holding funds by way of bank deposits," Ras said. "Bitcoin offers protection by way of decentralization, self-custody and a network that has never been hacked."

But a credit crisis poses the biggest downside risk for bitcoin, he said. In such a scenario, bitcoin as well as gold, another traditional safe-haven investment, could see a sharp decline in value.

"I'm not sure such a scenario would happen," Ras said, "but it's possible and would unleash a tremendous amount of volatility, not only for bitcoin but all markets."

title: Why Bitcoin Mixers Are a Double-Edged Sword for Anti-Money Laundering Efforts - Brave New Coin Insights
content:
Why Bitcoin Mixers Are a Double-Edged Sword for Anti-Money Laundering Efforts

Although bitcoin mixers are frequently targeted by financial regulators in relation to anti-money laundering efforts, they are also used for a range of legitimate purposes such as protecting financial privacy and avoiding nefarious transaction monitoring.

Bitcoin has become one of the world’s most popular forms of payment due to its convenience, speed, and low transaction fees. However, as more and more people use bitcoin for everyday transactions, privacy concerns have arisen. Bitcoin transactions are pseudo-anonymous, meaning that while transactions are recorded on a public blockchain, the identities of the sender and recipient are not necessarily known. This anonymity has made bitcoin a popular choice for those who value their privacy. However, the pseudo-anonymity of bitcoin has also made it attractive to criminals who use it for illegal activities such as money laundering. Since on-chain analytics companies can easily trace any blockchain transaction, more and more crypto users prefer coin-anonymizing services such as bitcoin mixers or bitcoin tumblers.

Bitcoin mixers have become a popular tool for those who want to keep their financial transactions private. While the concept of bitcoin mixers may seem innocent enough, they have become a double-edged sword in the fight against money laundering. According to a report by Chainalysis, a blockchain analytics company, the total value of bitcoin transferred through mixers increased from $11 million in 2022 to $67 million in 2023. This represents an increase of 500% in just one year. In this article, we will explore why bitcoin mixers are problematic for anti-money laundering efforts and how they can be used in a positive way.

The Dark Side of Bitcoin Mixers

Bitcoin mixers are online services that allow users to mix their bitcoins with other users’ bitcoins. This process is also known as bitcoin mixing or bitcoin tumbling. The idea behind bitcoin mixing is to make it difficult for anyone to trace a bitcoin transaction back to its original owner.

This anonymity is a major problem for anti-money laundering efforts. Criminals can use bitcoin mixers to launder money by mixing their illegally obtained bitcoins with legitimate ones. The process of mixing makes it almost impossible to trace the illegal bitcoins back to their original source.

According to a report by the Financial Action Task Force (FATF), an intergovernmental organization that develops anti-money laundering guidelines, bitcoin mixers are one of the biggest threats to anti-money laundering efforts in the cryptocurrency space. The report states that mixers are mostly used by criminals to launder money and avoid detection by law enforcement. Although cryptocurrencies are often singled out by politicians and enforcement agencies when discussing money laundering, the reality is that crypto-related money laundering is a drop in the bucket compared to the global money laundering total.

For example, in 2021 Chainalysis estimated around US$9 billion was laundered using cryptocurrencies. In the same time period, the United Nations office on Drugs and Crime estimated total global money laundering to be at least $800 billion annually – and potentially up to $2 trillion. Even more surprising is the number of respected international banks that were fined in 2021 in relation to breaches of anti-money laundering laws and regulations.

The Positive Side of Bitcoin Mixers

While bitcoin mixers are problematic for anti-money laundering efforts, they are also used for legitimate purposes. Many people use bitcoin mixers to protect their financial privacy and avoid potential transaction monitoring. For example, when someone buys something online using bitcoin, they may not want the seller to know their identity. By using a bitcoin mixer, they can ensure that their transaction is anonymous and cannot be traced back to them. Bitcoin mixing can help protect them from potential fraud or identity theft.

Bitcoin mixers are also often used by businesses to protect their financial information from competitors. If a company is making a large transaction, it may not want its competitors to know how much money it is moving. By using a bitcoin mixer, they can ensure that their transaction is private and cannot be traced back to them.

Another reason for seeking transaction privacy is political persecution. Of 205 countries and territories surveyed by Freedom House recently, in terms of their political rights and civil liberties, the NGO found 125 to be either ‘not free’ or only ‘partly free’. Political movements are costly to organise, and cutting of access to funding is a common tactic of oppressive governments.

In terms of personal security, bitcoin mixers can be used by law-abiding citizens to protect themselves from hacking and theft. By mixing their bitcoins with others, users can disguise the origin of their funds, making it more difficult for hackers to target them.

Tendencies to Regulate the Use of Bitcoin Mixers

As bitcoin has grown in popularity, there have been attempts by governments and regulators to bring it under their control. This has led to discussions about the regulation of bitcoin mixers, which are seen by some as only a tool for money laundering. In some countries, bitcoin mixers are currently illegal or operate in a legal gray area.

For example, in the United States, the use of bitcoin mixers is considered a violation of anti-money laundering laws, while in Japan, bitcoin mixers can only operate if they are licensed by the government. Similarly, in the European Union, bitcoin mixers are subject to anti-money laundering regulations and must comply with Know Your Customer (KYC) and Anti-Money Laundering (AML) requirements.

Conclusion

Bitcoin mixers are a double-edged sword for anti-money laundering efforts. While they can be used for illicit purposes, they also have legitimate uses in protecting financial privacy and preventing hacking and theft. It is important for governments and regulators to strike a balance between preventing illicit activity and protecting the legitimate uses of bitcoin mixers. Furthermore, the positive aspects of bitcoin mixers should not be overlooked. They are an important tool for individuals and businesses seeking to protect their financial privacy and secure their funds. The use of bitcoin mixers can help increase the adoption and mainstream acceptance of cryptocurrencies, which can lead to greater financial inclusion and economic empowerment. To fully realize the benefits of bitcoin mixers, it is important to promote transparency and collaboration between governments, regulators, and the cryptocurrency community. By working together, we can ensure that bitcoin mixers are used in a way that is responsible, legal, and beneficial for everyone. Ultimately, bitcoin mixers are an important tool in the cryptocurrency landscape that can be used for both good and bad. By recognizing their potential and working to mitigate their negative effects, we can create a safer and fairer financial system for all.
